data.title: Paramount seals the deal with Warner, expects EU approvals to be easy
data.description:
Paramount Skydance (PSKY) expects to secure antitrust approvals comfortably in Europe to buy Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD) and would consider divestments if necessary, Reuters reported on Friday, citing two sources.

Sources told the news outlet that EU concerns regarding divestments will likely be minor.

Paramount's offer faces fewer regulatory hurdles because a combined Paramount and Warner Bros. has a market share of below 20% in all markets across Europe, sources told Reuters.

Earlier today, Warner Bros. signed the deal with Paramount, according to an audio clip of a global town hall by the company, which was reviewed by Reuters.

"Netflix (NFLX) had the legal right to match the PSKY offer. As you all know, they ultimately decided not to do that. That then resulted in a signed agreement with PSKY as of this morning. So that's where everything stands," Bruce Campbell, Warner Bros.' chief revenue and strategy officer, reportedly said during the town hall.

However, the deal would require approval under the EU's foreign subsidies regulation because Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund, Abu Dhabi's L'imad Holding Company, and the Qatar Investment Authority are also bankrolling the bid, the report said. The FSR targets unfair foreign state aid.

According to the report, the company may be willing to divest minor channels such as its children's brands if required. Overlapping businesses include the combination of two studios and several TV channels.

Outside the U.S., David Ellison has been busy trying to convince regulators, notably in the UK, Germany, and France, while his recently appointed legal chief, Makan Delrahim, met the European Commission's top merger official, Guillaume Loriot.

European Parliament lawmaker Andreas Schwab, who was against Netflix's bid and met Delrahim last month, said a Paramount bid poses fewer issues.

"I think Paramount is something we could accept. It is a concentration in the production of films. There is no risk of a digital champion taking over the video streaming market," Schwab said.

PSKY shares are up nearly 24%, NFLX is up 13%, and WBD is down nearly 2% in late afternoon trading.

data.title: Catalyst Watch: Jobs report, new Apple products, and a spotlight on software
data.description:
Welcome to Seeking Alpha's Catalyst Watch - a breakdown of some of next week's actionable events that stand out. Read more about the events that may impact stock prices next week.

 

Sunday - March 1

  • All day - Eight key OPEC+ nations will hold their monthly video conference and decide on production levels for April.
  • Data watch - Key data reports expected to arrive include deliveries reports from Nio (NIO), XPeng (XPEV), Li Auto (LI), and BYD Company (BYDDF), as well as the monthly Macau gross gaming revenue release.

 

Monday - March 2

  • Volatility watch - AST SpaceMobile (ASTS) and Xenon Pharmaceuticals (XENE) are set up for a volatile week of trading based on options volume. The most overbought stocks per their 14-day relative strength index include ATI Inc. (ATI), Keysight (KEYS), and Nordic American Tankers (NAT). The most oversold stocks per their 14-day Relative Strength Index include Gossamer Bio (GOSS), FuboTV (FUBO), and Oddity Tech (ODD). Short interest is elevated on software stocks UiPath (PATH), Duolingo (DUOL), Coreweave (CRWV), and RingCentral (RNG).
  • Earnings watch - Notable companies due to report include Progressive (PGR), MongoDB (MDB), Riot Platforms (RIOT), and EchoStar (SATS). Options trading implies a double-digit swing in share price for AST SpaceMobile (ASTS) and Asana (ASAN) after they report.
  • Dividend watch - Companies that have an ex-dividend date coming next week include Allstate (ALL), Lam Research (LRCX), Cigna (CI), and Qualcomm (QCOM).
  • IPO watch - MiniMed Group (MMED) will start trading after being separated from Medtronic (MDT), which will still own about 90% of the company. The analyst quiet period expires on Forgent Power Solutions (FPS), Eikon Therapeutics (EIKN), Bob’s Discount Furniture (BOBS), and VeraDermics (MANE) to free up analysts to post ratings.
  • All week - The Department of Justice antitrust trial against Live Nation–Ticketmaster (LYV) will take place.
  • All day - The three-day Morgan Stanley Technology, Media & Telecom Conference in San Francisco will begin. Some of the notable companies participating include Walmart (WMT), Cisco (CSCO), Disney (DIS), Comcast (CMCSA), Expedia (EXPE), Amdocs (DOX), Autodesk (ADSK), NetApp (NTAP), and Carvana (CVNA).
  • All day - The Mobile World Congress Barcelona event will begin. Notable companies participating include Cisco (CSCO), Qualcomm (QCOM), AT&T (T), and SpaceX (SPACE).
  • All day - DraftKings (DKNG) will also host a virtual Investor Day. Management is expected to share views on the opportunity ahead, outline the company’s sustainable advantages, and discuss financial framework and capital allocation priorities.

 

Tuesday - March 3

  • Earnings watch - Notable companies due to report include Crowdstrike (CRWD), Ross Stores (ROST), Autozone (AZO), Target (TGT), Best Buy (BBY), On Holding (ONON), and Box (BOX). Options trading implies a double-digit swing in share price for Sportradar (SRAD) and Webtoon Entertainment (WBTN) after they report.
  • M&A watch - Shareholders with Amicus Therapeutics (FOLD) vote on the proposed merger with BioMarin Pharmaceutical (BMRN). Amicus traded about 1.1% below the deal price at the time of publication. Shareholders with Ventyx Biosciences (VTYX) will vote on the buyout offer from Eli Lilly (LLY). 
  • All day - The four-day CONEXPO-CON/AGG Conference will begin in Las Vegas. The conference is considered the key international gathering for the construction, aggregates, and ready-mixed concrete industries. Widely regarded as the premier international event for the sector, the once-every-three-year gathering also provides a meaningful boost in visitor traffic for major Strip operators, including MGM Resorts (MGM), Caesars Entertainment (CZR), and Wynn Resorts (WYNN).
  • 9:55 a.m. Federal Reserve Bank of New York President John Williams will give a keynote address at the America’s Credit Unions Governmental Affairs Conference.
  • 11:55 a.m. Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis President Neel Kashkari will speak at the Bloomberg Invest Conference.

 

Wednesday - March 4

  • Earnings watch - Notable companies due to report include Broadcom (AVGO), VEEVA Systems (VEEV), Brown-Forman (BF.A) (BF.B), and Okta (OKTA). Options trading implies a double-digit swing in share price for Genius Sports (GENI) and StubHub (STUB) after they report.
  • All day - Apple (AAPL) has invited press and creators to in-person "Apple Experience" sessions in New York, London, and Shanghai as part of its coordinated announcements of new iPad/Mac products.
  • All day - Lennox (LII) will host its Investor Day event in the Dallas-Fort Worth area. The program will feature formal presentations from top management as they outline the company's operational progress, strategic priorities, and new long-term growth targets.
  • All day - Pentair (PNR) will host its Investor Day event.
  • 2:00 p.m. The Federal Reserve will release its Beige Book Report. The report will summarize current economic conditions across the Fed's districts.
  • 4:50 p.m. Netflix (NFLX) CFO Spence Neumann will participate in a Q&A session at the Morgan Stanley Technology, Media & Telecom Conference.

 

Thursday - March 5

  • Earnings watch - Notable companies due to report include Costco Wholesale (COST), Petrobras (PBR), Marvell Technology (MRVL), Kroger (KR), JD.com (JD), and Guidewire Software (GWRE). Options trading implies double-digit swings for Ciena (CIEN) and Victoria's Secret (VSCO) after they report.
  • All day - China's National People's Congress will hold its annual session. The event could signal China's macro policy direction, influencing global markets through targets on GDP growth, fiscal stimulus, and sectors like tech and AI.
  • 11:00 a.m. Caterpillar (CAT) Chief Executive Officer Joe Creed and Construction Industries Group President Rod Shurman are expected to participate in a fireside chat at the CONEXPO Conference in Las Vegas.

 

Friday - March 6

  • All day - The Manheim Used Vehicle Value Index will be released.
  • All day - It is the record date for the Booking Holdings 25-for-1 stock split. The company has not executed a stock split since 2003.
  • All day - The United Nations will release its latest FAO Food Price Index and monthly grains report, which are watched by commodities traders.
  • All day - It is the FDA action date for Bristol Myers Squibb’s (BMY) supplemental New Drug Application for Sotyktu (deucravacitinib) to treat adults with active psoriatic arthritis.
  • 8:30 a.m. The January Retail Sales report will be released by the U.S. Census Bureau.
  • 8:30 a.m. The February jobs report will be released. Economists expect 62K job additions for the month and for the unemployment rate to remain at 4.4%.

 

Seeking Alpha Editor Josh Fineman contributed to this article.

data.title: Bayer releases promising early-stage data on prostate cancer therapy
data.description:
• Bayer (BAYRY) said that phase 1 data on 225Ac-PSMA-Trillium (BAY 3563254), a next-generation targeted alpha therapy, showed that the treatment led to an 83% disease control rate and no patients had dose-limiting toxicities.
  • The overall response rate across all doses tested was 46%. PSA50 and PSA90 response rates were 58% and 36% overall, and 83% and 58% at the recommended dose for expansion.
  • The German pharma said that the results support advancing the candidate into the next development phase.
  • Bayer (BAYZF) noted that targeted alpha therapies such as 225Ac-PSMA-Trillium are an "emerging class of radionuclide therapy" against multiple tumor types that can deliver "alpha particle radiation directly to the tumor inside the body."
  • Bayer gained the asset through its 2021 acquisition of PSMA Therapeutics and Noria Therapeutics.

data.title: Baidu shares slide for a seventh straight session
data.description:
Shares of Baidu (BIDU) fell 0.52% to $124.50 in the afternoon trade on Friday, extending losses for a seventh session.

The stock had fell around 8.72% between February 19 to February 26, compared to a 0.68% gain of the S&P 500 during the same period.

Shares of the company edged lower amid a mix of company-specific news and broader market pressures weighed on sentiment. The company reported mixed fourth-quarter results, beating profit estimates but missing on revenue while its core business revenue declined for a third straight quarter, even as it announced a $5 billion buyback and its first dividend.

At the same time, it fell after being briefly mentioned in a U.S. government list tied to Chinese military links, which unsettled investors despite the list being withdrawn. The decline also came amid broader weakness in technology stocks, and cautious global market sentiment driven by interest rate uncertainty and geopolitical tensions. 

According to Seeking Alpha’s Quant Rating system, BIDU is rated Hold, with a score of 3.15 out of 5, receiving an A- for momentum but a D- for growth.

A Seeking Alpha analyst said the company’s traditional business remains under pressure even as it pushes into AI, noting that “Baidu's core search business faces structural challenges with stagnant MAU and declining ARPU,” and adding that “the business is still facing stagnation, particularly from its bread-and-butter, search and ads, which represent over 50% of revenue.” They also pointed out that while AI initiatives such as chips and autonomous driving are gaining momentum, “these don't offer the same level of profitability and are thus a major headwind.”

On the Wall Street, 27 of 33 analysts rate the stock Buy or higher, five recommend Hold, and one recommends a Sell.

Shares have fell around 21% in the past one month and have gained approximately 4% year-to-date.

data.title: Fidus outlines $0.52 Q1 2026 dividend as deal flow rebounds from pent-up demand
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Fidus Investment (FDUS) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Edward Ross, Chairman of the Board & CEO, highlighted that "deal flow was strong, driven by a healthy M&A environment compared to earlier in the year. This resulted in originations of $213.7 million, the highest amount of capital we have invested in a quarter." He attributed the surge to pent-up demand following Liberation Day and noted several deals spilled over from the third quarter. Ross emphasized disciplined underwriting, stating Fidus continues to invest in niche market leaders with recurring revenue and structured debt with significant loan-to-value cushions.
  • The company's total portfolio reached $1.3 billion on a fair value basis. Adjusted NII for Q4 was $19.4 million, up 5.1%, and the company paid total dividends of $0.50 per share for the quarter. Net asset value grew to $741.9 million, or $19.55 per share.
  • For Q1 2026, Ross announced, "the Board of Directors declared a total dividend of $0.52 per share, which consists of a base dividend of $0.43 per share and a supplemental dividend of $0.09 per share."
  • Shelby Sherard, CFO, stated, "Total investment income was $42.2 million for the 3 months ended December 31, a $4.9 million increase from Q3, primarily driven by a $2 million increase in interest income as a result of increased average debt investments outstanding and which includes a $0.3 million of accelerated amortization of closing fees related to debt repayments, a $3.5 million increase in fee income given an increase in investment activity in Q4, which was partially offset by a $0.8 million decrease in dividend income from equity investments."

Outlook

  • Ross stated, "We expect activity levels will pick up during the year as some private equity owners are likely to need to bring certain portfolio companies to market. As we deploy capital, we intend to stay focused on our long-term goals of generating attractive risk-adjusted returns for our shareholders and growing net-asset-value over time."
  • He noted that deal flow in Q1 2026 is "a little more modest in nature" but expected activity to increase as the year progresses.

Financial Results

  • Net investment income (NII) for Q4 was $0.53 per share, while adjusted NII was $0.52 per share, both increased compared to Q3.
  • Portfolio at fair value ended at $1.3 billion, with $658.3 million in debt outstanding. The weighted average interest rate on debt was 5.2% as of December 31.
  • Weighted average effective yield on debt investments was 12.6% as of December 31, compared to 13% at the end of Q3. Nonaccruals accounted for less than 1% of the portfolio on a fair value basis.
  • Liquidity at year-end included $79.6 million in cash, $141.2 million availability on the line of credit, and $84 million of available SBA debentures, totaling approximately $304.8 million.

Q&A

  • Robert Dodd, Raymond James: Asked about deal flow spillover into Q1 and whether activity would be more modest after the Q4 ramp. Chairman Ross responded, “Q4 was a quarter where most things kind of came to fruition... I think now in Q1 '26, deal flow is a little more modest in nature. We believe it's somewhat due to seasonal patterns... our current expectations are for an increase in both deal flow and activity throughout the year.”
  • Dodd also probed on software business risk, especially regarding AI. Ross explained, “We believe the recent headlines, although meaningful and serious, the market dislocation in software has been blown out of proportion from our perspective... we're looking for companies that have things like data moats... vertical markets, specialized industry software... contractual revenue streams... management is critical.”
  • Mickey Schleien, Clear Street LLC: Inquired about ARR loans. Ross replied, "about 22% of our software portfolio today or 7.5% of our total portfolio are ARR loans as we sit here today... when we structure an ARR loan, we force growth through covenants... and we also force a transition to cash flow."
  • Schleien asked about the concentration in Pfanstiehl. Ross replied, "we are extremely comfortable with that position. I think the long-term outlook for that business, they're a leader in their space... we feel good about it today."
  • Schleien questioned the dividend outlook from Pfanstiehl; Ross noted dividends are "episodic in nature, but also reoccurring annually in some way, shape or form."
  • Schleien asked about floating rate debt floors; Ross stated, "Most of our floors that we've been originating here over the last, let's say, 3, 4 years are in the 2% range."
  • Christopher Nolan, Ladenburg Thalmann: Queried on M&A drivers and software company deleveraging. Ross indicated pent-up demand from PE is the main M&A driver, and "we are seeing deleveraging, whether it's an ARR loan or it's EBITDA-based loan."
  • Paul Johnson, KBW: Asked about recovery rates on first lien loans. Ross estimated historical recoveries in the 60%-85% range and emphasized the 37% loan-to-value provides a significant cushion.
  • Dylan Haynes, B. Riley Securities: Asked about deployment trends in software/tech and pricing. Ross stated Fidus remains focused on best-in-class software names and expects unique opportunities from recent market dislocation.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts maintained a generally positive tone but sought detailed risk disclosures, especially regarding sector exposures and portfolio concentration. Questions were probing yet constructive, with a focus on sustainability and risk management.
  • Management's tone was confident and slightly more detailed when discussing portfolio quality and risk controls. Ross repeatedly emphasized comfort with concentrations and underwriting discipline, and used phrases like "we feel good about it" and "we are extremely comfortable" when discussing key positions and risk areas.
  • Compared to the previous quarter, both analysts and management exhibited increased attention to software/AI risks and portfolio concentrations, but management's confidence level remained steady and slightly upbeat.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Q4 saw a marked increase in deal originations ($213.7 million vs. $74.5 million in Q3), attributed to pent-up M&A demand following market disruptions earlier in the year.
  • Adjusted NII per share rose to $0.52 in Q4 from $0.50 in Q3. Net asset value increased to $741.9 million from $711 million. Dividend per share for Q1 2026 was declared at $0.52, higher than the $0.50 declared for Q4 in the previous call.
  • Strategic focus shifted to more detailed software/tech sector disclosure and risk mitigation, with increased discussion of AI and ARR exposures.
  • Analysts in Q4 pressed more on the specifics of portfolio risk, especially in the software sector, compared to Q3's broader focus on market activity and macro risks (e.g., tariffs, government shutdown).
  • Management's sentiment remained consistently confident, with more emphasis on underwriting standards and sector strategy in Q4.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management highlighted ongoing attention to AI risks within the software and tech-enabled services portfolio, which totaled $464 million, with 92% first-lien debt and an average loan-to-value of 37%.
  • Nonaccruals remained low, but management continues to monitor sector and company-specific risks, especially in concentrated positions like Pfanstiehl and in the face of interest rate changes.
  • Analysts raised concerns about portfolio concentration, sustainability of dividend income from key holdings, floating rate exposure to declining SOFR, and the impact of M&A market dynamics.
  • Management's mitigation strategies include strict underwriting, structured covenants, portfolio diversification, and a focus on first-lien security.

Final Takeaway

Fidus Investment delivered a record quarter for deal originations, driven by a rebound in M&A activity and pent-up demand. The company outlined a clear focus on underwriting discipline, robust credit quality, and risk-adjusted returns, with enhanced transparency on software and tech portfolio exposures, including AI-related risks. Management expects deal flow and investment activity to build through 2026, supported by strong liquidity and a disciplined approach to capital deployment, while maintaining confidence in portfolio quality and dividend sustainability.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Tcpc signals portfolio repositioning with 87.4% first lien loans amid NAV decline
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: BlackRock TCP Capital Corp. (TCPC) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Philip Tseng, CEO, noted a challenging quarter, stating that "Full year 2025 adjusted NII was $1.22 per share compared to $1.52 in 2024. Annualized NII ROE for the year was 12.3% compared to 14.5% in 2024." He attributed the decline in NII to "portfolio markdowns and nonaccruals as well as lower base rates and tighter spreads year-over-year." Adjusted NII for the fourth quarter was $0.25 per share, down from $0.30 in the previous quarter and $0.36 in the same quarter last year.
  • Tseng highlighted significant portfolio markdowns, with NAV dropping 19% to $7.07 per share as of December 31, 2025, from $8.71 at September 30. Six portfolio companies accounted for approximately 67% or $1.11 per share of the NAV decline, with Edmentum, Razor, SellerX, Renovo, Hylan, and InMobi named as key contributors.
  • The CEO announced a first quarter dividend of $0.17 per share and detailed share repurchases during and after the quarter totaling 749,410 shares.
  • Jason Mehring, President, outlined that the portfolio stood at $1.5 billion across 141 companies, with 92.4% invested in senior secured loans and 7.5% in equity. "All new portfolio company investments during 2025 were in first lien loans, bringing total portfolio exposure to first lien loans to 87.4% on a fair value basis, up from 83.6% last year."
  • Mehring discussed new investments, including a $4.5 million first lien term loan to a wealth management platform and a $4 million first lien loan to Coalfire, a cybersecurity provider, emphasizing a strategy of direct origination and increased portfolio diversification.
  • Erik Cuellar, CFO, stated, "Gross investment income for the fourth quarter was $0.52 per share," including "recurring cash interest of $0.41, nonrecurring income of $0.01, recurring discount and fee amortization of $0.02, PIK income of $0.06 and dividend income of $0.02 per share."
  • Cuellar also reported, "Net realized losses for the quarter were $73.9 million or $0.87 per share... Net unrealized losses were $66.5 million or $0.78 per share, primarily due to the unrealized markdowns on the 6 investments Phil discussed earlier."

Outlook

  • Management reiterated its focus on improving credit quality and repositioning toward first lien loans and greater portfolio diversification. Tseng stated, "Our highest near-term priority is to improve the credit quality of our investment portfolio by working diligently to resolve challenged credits."
  • The dividend was set at $0.17 per share for Q1 2026, with the goal of maintaining a sustainable and NII-covered dividend.

Financial Results

  • Adjusted net investment income for Q4 was $0.25 per share, compared to $0.30 in Q3 and $0.36 in Q4 2024.
  • NAV declined to $7.07 per share at December 31, 2025, down from $8.71 at September 30.
  • Nonaccrual debt investments represented 4% of the portfolio at fair value and 9.7% at cost.
  • Total liquidity at year-end was $570.2 million, with $482.8 million in available borrowings and $61.1 million of cash. Net regulatory leverage was 1.41x at year-end, up from 1.2x in the previous quarter.
  • The company paid down its entire $325 million principal amount of 2026 unsecured notes post year-end.

Q&A

  • Robert Dodd, Raymond James: Questioned whether more aggressive strategic adjustments might be warranted given portfolio contraction and rising leverage. Philip Tseng responded, "We continually evaluate ways to optimize returns for the shareholders. And at this time, we believe the best path forward is to continue to focus on improving the credit quality of the portfolio and executing on the investment strategy that we've been discussing."
  • Dodd also asked about the effectiveness of restructurings and whether more aggressive approaches were needed. Tseng replied, "Restructurings, they can play out in several different ways. The road to recovery... are not always linear. In fact, they're rarely linear."
  • Finian O'Shea, Wells Fargo: Inquired about the rationale behind the significant NAV markdowns and the unusual timing of the 8-K filing. Jason Mehring responded, "There hasn't been any sort of change to our valuation policy... when you look at the overall write-downs in the quarter, they were concentrated fairly heavily among those 6 names... had an equity orientation, which... is more volatile." Mehring emphasized the idiosyncratic nature of the events and said the 8-K was a one-off due to the magnitude and concentration of markdowns.

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed skepticism regarding the pace of portfolio turnaround, the need for more aggressive strategic action, and the stickiness of restructurings, with pointed questions about the viability of current plans and the causes behind NAV declines.
  • Management maintained a neutral to slightly defensive tone, emphasizing ongoing execution of their strategy and the complexity of credit recoveries. Tseng asserted, "We are confident in our strategy."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, both analysts and management exhibited increased caution, with more direct questioning from analysts and more extended explanations and justifications from management.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance language shifted from optimism about stabilization and diversification in Q3 to acknowledgment of significant NAV declines and the need for portfolio repositioning in Q4.
  • Strategic focus increased on first lien loans and diversification, with the percentage of first lien loans rising from 83.6% to 87.4%.
  • Key metrics deteriorated: NAV fell from $8.71 to $7.07 per share, and adjusted NII dropped from $0.30 to $0.25 per share.
  • Analysts' tone moved from cautious to pressing, seeking clarity on strategic alternatives and the efficacy of restructuring processes.
  • Management's confidence in the investment strategy remained, but explanations were longer and more focused on remediation.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited portfolio markdowns and nonaccruals as major challenges, especially in investments underwritten before 2022.
  • Six specific portfolio companies were responsible for most of the NAV decline.
  • Equity-oriented positions were highlighted as particularly volatile.
  • Tseng noted the need to "work diligently with our borrowers, their sponsors and creditors to optimize recovery values, including pursuing restructurings and other transaction-driven outcomes when appropriate."
  • Analysts raised concerns about restructuring effectiveness and the potential need for more aggressive strategic shifts.

Final Takeaway

Management emphasized the ongoing repositioning of the portfolio toward first lien senior secured loans and greater diversification, acknowledging significant NAV and NII declines driven by concentrated markdowns in legacy investments. The company reiterated its commitment to resolving challenged credits and leveraging BlackRock’s resources, with the aim of gradually improving portfolio quality and delivering sustainable returns to shareholders.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Northwest Natural aims for 4%–6% EPS growth and unveils $300M MX3 storage expansion as Texas and water segments accelerate
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Northwest Natural Holding Company (NWN) Q4 2025

Management View

  • CEO Justin Palfreyman highlighted, "We delivered record adjusted earnings per share at the top of our guidance range, deployed a record amount of capital to support our customers and reported our strongest organic customer growth in nearly 2 decades." He noted the company is "excited to announce our new MX3 storage expansion project in the Pacific Northwest, a project that will enhance regional reliability and capacity and one that has the potential to drive our long-term earnings growth target to 5% to 7% once we receive notice to proceed."
  • Palfreyman addressed regulatory progress: "We successfully settled our Oregon rate case in 2025 with new rates effective October 31. In Washington, I'm pleased to report that we've been working collaboratively and productively with parties and have reached settlement in principle, resolving the revenue requirement in the case."
  • The CEO emphasized the integration and growth of Texas assets: "SiEnergy provided 18% organic customer growth in 2025 and contributed 11% of our consolidated adjusted earnings per share. At the same time, SiEnergy posted a sizable increase to its customer backlog nearing 250,000 future meters."
  • Palfreyman stated on the water segment, "The Water segment outperformed our expectations, contributing $0.35 per share or 12% of our consolidated adjusted earnings per share in 2025."
  • CFO Raymond Kaszuba said, "For the full year 2025, we reported record adjusted earnings per share of $2.93 compared to $2.33 per share for 2024. Earnings growth was fueled by new rates in Oregon, healthy rate base growth across the business and continued strong organic customer growth."
  • Kaszuba added, "For 2026 specifically, we expect another record year for both capital investment and earnings. At the same time, we are focused on returning capital to shareholders."

Outlook

  • The company is initiating 2026 earnings per share guidance of $2.95 to $3.15 and reaffirming its long-term earnings per share growth rate of 4% to 6% compounded annually from 2025 adjusted earnings per share through 2030.
  • Palfreyman indicated that if the MX3 project receives notice to proceed, "we expect that we will increase that to the 5% to 7% that we just described."
  • The company expects SiEnergy and Northwest Natural Water to contribute approximately 25% of consolidated earnings for 2026.
  • Capital expenditures for 2026 are anticipated at approximately $500 million to $550 million, with a five-year CapEx plan of $2.6 billion to $2.9 billion through 2030.

Financial Results

  • Adjusted earnings per share for 2025 reached $2.93, up from $2.33 in 2024.
  • Cash provided by operating activities was approximately $270 million, about 35% above 2024.
  • Record capital investment of $467 million was made in 2025, with $340 million allocated to acquisitions.
  • SiEnergy contributed $0.33 per share for 2025, above initial expectations.
  • Water segment earnings per share increased $0.21 and contributed $0.35 per share, also above expectations.
  • Year-end liquidity stood at approximately $590 million.

Q&A

  • Christopher Ellinghaus, Siebert Williams Shank: Asked about the impact of MX3 on growth guidance and project timeline. Palfreyman responded, "Without MX3, we are very comfortable with our 4% to 6% long-term EPS growth guidance. With the project, once that achieves notice to proceed, we expect that we will increase that to the 5% to 7% that we just described."
  • Ellinghaus inquired about SiEnergy's performance. Palfreyman said, "We've been really pleased with the growth that we've seen at SiEnergy despite a slowdown in the housing market in Texas, we had incredible growth this year."
  • Ellinghaus asked about the Oregon rate mechanism. Palfreyman confirmed, "We are expecting receipt of that, the rate mechanism here in Oregon as part of that guidance. It is a relatively modest increase to rates, about 1.5%."
  • Ellinghaus queried about water segment M&A strategy. Palfreyman stated, "We're always looking opportunistically at acquisition opportunities... but we are really happy with the platform that we have built."
  • Alexis Kania, BTIG: Asked about MX3 funding and AFUDC. Kaszuba responded, "We would be able to fund any equity through normal issuances under our ATM. And then... yes, we would also receive AFUDC during the construction period."
  • Selman Akyol, Stifel: Asked about further storage expansion and behind-the-meter opportunities. Palfreyman said, "There is strong customer demand... It's very premature to comment on any specifics there. In terms of behind-the-meter opportunities, it is something we've been approached by numerous customers... If there is a storage potential use case there, but there's nothing that we have today to announce on that front."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts were positive, focusing on growth drivers, regulatory clarity, and strategic expansions, frequently congratulating management and probing for details on forward growth and project execution.
  • Management maintained a confident and optimistic tone, especially in the prepared remarks. Palfreyman stated, "I have never been more confident in our strategy, our team and our future."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, the tone remained upbeat, but with a greater emphasis on execution, new project milestones, and confidence in outpacing previous trends.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • The current quarter featured the announcement of the MX3 storage expansion project, which was not discussed previously.
  • Guidance was reaffirmed at 4% to 6% EPS growth, with a new potential increase to 5% to 7% if MX3 proceeds.
  • SiEnergy and Water segments are now expected to contribute a greater proportion of consolidated earnings, reflecting their rapid growth.
  • Management's tone shifted from steady confidence to heightened optimism, underpinned by record results and new project developments.
  • Analyst questions evolved to focus more on execution timelines and the specifics of longer-term growth drivers.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited the need to finalize EPC contracts and some local permits before achieving notice to proceed for MX3.
  • There are considerations about the timing and execution of a rate case for SiEnergy, with Palfreyman noting ongoing evaluation of regulatory mechanisms in Texas.
  • While the water segment's growth is strong, management is balancing organic growth with opportunistic acquisitions, indicating a measured approach to expansion.
  • The company highlighted the importance of maintaining affordability for customers and managing rate impacts, especially in light of capital investments and regulatory changes.

Final Takeaway

Northwest Natural Holding Company concluded 2025 with record adjusted earnings per share and robust capital deployment, underscoring the success of its diversification strategy. The announcement of the $300 million MX3 storage expansion signals a new phase of regional growth and improved earnings visibility, with the potential to elevate long-term EPS growth targets. Management reaffirmed confidence in the company’s platform, highlighted strong performances from both the Texas and water segments, and laid out clear plans for future capital investments, all while maintaining a focus on customer affordability and shareholder returns.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: AEP upgraded at UBS as stock re-rating looks sustainable
data.description:
American Electric Power (AEP) +1.3% in Friday's trading as UBS upgraded shares to Neutral from Sell with a $132 price target, raised from $115, saying the utility looks well positioned for higher EPS growth of 8%-9% through 2030, compared to last year's 7% midpoint projection.

AEP (AEP) holds the largest backlog of major load contracts at 56 GW and boasts the largest
transmission network, supporting its growth potential, while also benefiting from improved regulatory tools in Ohio and Texas, which could start to deliver a 40-50 bp increase in earned return on equity, UBS analyst William Appicelli wrote.

However, further efforts are needed to fully leverage large load contracts and enhance ROEs, the analyst said, and while he remains cautious about whether management can deliver the promised substantial load growth, the increased capital expenditure and the fact that investors will not have confirmation of the load growth guidance for several years make the risk profile more balanced over the next year.

Currently trading at a ~4% premium to the bank's new 2028 estimate, Appicelli said he sees AEP (AEP) shares as fairly valued, reflecting both the expected outcomes and pricing in 8% EPS growth consistent with his forecast.

data.title: CG Oncology GAAP EPS of -$2.08 beats by $0.09, revenue of $4.04M beats by $1.24M
data.description:
• CG Oncology press release (CGON): FY GAAP EPS of -$2.08 beats by $0.09.
  • Revenue of $4.04M (+254.4% Y/Y) beats by $1.24M.

data.title: Delek Logistics anticipates $520M–$560M EBITDA in 2026 amid record Q4 performance and Permian growth
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Delek Logistics Partners, LP (DKL) Q4 2025

Management View

  • Avigal Soreq, President and CEO, highlighted a record adjusted EBITDA of $536 million for 2025 and emphasized strong execution across natural gas, crude, and water businesses. Soreq noted, "We continued to advance our key initiatives across our natural gas, crude and water businesses, increasing our position as a premier full service provider in the Permian Basin."
  • Soreq discussed the successful commissioning of the Libby 2 processing plant, increasing capacity to around 160 million scf per day, and the expansion of acid gas injection and sour gas handling solutions. He stated, "We are very excited about providing this comprehensive capability to our customers, further supporting long-term oil and gas production growth in the Delaware Basin."
  • The integration of H2O and Gravity was described as largely complete, with the combined offering strengthening DKL's competitive position.
  • Soreq announced 2026 EBITDA guidance of $520 million to $560 million and the 52nd consecutive quarterly distribution increase to $1.125 per unit.
  • Reuven Spiegel, EVP of Special Projects, noted, "In 2026, we expect approximately 80% of our run rate EBITDA will come from third parties. This is an extraordinary achievement for the partnership and its increased independence will allow us to be more nimble."
  • Spiegel addressed the ramp-up of the sour gas solution, stating, "While our ramp-up has been slower versus our initial expectations, the need for sour gas solution is urgent, and we expect to see a step change in our utilization once our AGI and sour gas gathering infrastructure is fully complete."
  • Robert Wright, EVP and Deputy CFO, stated, "We ended 2025 in a strong financial position with approximately $940 million available liquidity under our credit facilities."

Outlook

  • Management provided a 2026 EBITDA guidance range of $520 million to $560 million, reflecting anticipated growth opportunities while managing leverage and coverage.
  • Soreq stated, "We are confident in our ability to continue delivering sustainable growth and long-term value for our unitholders."
  • Guidance language emphasized a focus on strategic expansion across the Permian Basin and continued discipline in capital allocation.

Financial Results

  • Adjusted EBITDA for Q4 2025 reached approximately $142 million, up from $114 million in Q4 2024 and $6 million higher than the previous quarter's record.
  • Distributable cash flow as adjusted was $73 million, with a DCF coverage ratio of approximately 1.22x.
  • Gathering and Processing segment adjusted EBITDA was $71 million, up from $66 million in the prior year, primarily due to the H2O and Gravity acquisitions.
  • Wholesale Marketing and Terminalling adjusted EBITDA held steady at $21 million compared to the previous year.
  • Storage and Transportation adjusted EBITDA was $35 million, compared with $18 million in Q4 2024, reflecting the impact of asset sales to DK.
  • Investments in Pipeline Joint Venture contributed $26 million, up from $18 million in the prior year, driven by strong performance from the Wink to Webster joint venture.
  • Total capital spending for the quarter was approximately $32 million, with $26 million allocated to growth capital, primarily for sour gas capabilities at the Libby Complex.

Q&A

  • Douglas Irwin, Citigroup: Asked about the variance in guidance range and the impact of G&P performance and sour gas ramp-up; Soreq detailed the accretive returns from current investments and highlighted the "growth and yield combination that we are seeing, that's probably best-in-class."
  • Irwin: Inquired about the EBITDA impact from asset transactions with DK and future opportunities; Wright responded, "DKL now has 82% of their EBITDA is now from third-party businesses as a result of this transaction."
  • Gabriel Moreen, Mizuho Securities: Probed next steps for Libby processing expansion; Soreq said, "We are looking very, very carefully...what our customer and producers are doing in the area. And in our area looks very good, and which means 2 things, which means more sour and which means more volume, both on the crude and gas."
  • Moreen: Asked about midstream M&A in sour gas; Soreq responded, "We are not shy of doing that, but we are not going to force ourselves into a deal that it's too expensive...Every deal that we do needs to be accretive to free cash flow, leverage ratio and coverage ratio."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts posed detailed questions on growth, guidance, asset transactions, and expansion, with a neutral to slightly positive tone focused on operational execution and capital discipline.
  • Management maintained a confident tone during prepared remarks, frequently referencing record results and strategic achievements. Soreq stated, "We are very happy about that."
  • The Q&A session saw management provide comprehensive answers, with occasional hesitation on specifics. The tone remained confident, with language like "we are very excited" and "we are looking very good."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s confidence persisted, while analysts remained focused on operational execution and capital allocation.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for 2026 was provided, compared to the Q3 call where guidance was limited to the upper end of a $500 million to $520 million range for 2025.
  • The focus on third-party EBITDA increased, from discussions of independence in Q3 to the specific metric of 80% third-party EBITDA in Q4.
  • Both quarters highlighted the importance of the Libby 2 plant and sour gas solutions, but Q4 emphasized the urgency and expected "step change" in utilization in 2026.
  • Capital discipline and acquisition integration remained key themes, while the Q4 call signaled ongoing evaluation of further expansion and M&A with caution on valuation.
  • Analyst sentiment remained generally inquisitive, with recurring questions on growth, guidance, and capital priorities.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management noted that the ramp-up in sour gas infrastructure has been slower than initially expected, but described the need for sour gas solutions as urgent.
  • The company cited ongoing capital discipline as critical, with Soreq stating future deals must be "accretive to free cash flow, leverage ratio and coverage ratio."
  • Analyst questions reflected concerns about the timeline for full utilization of new processing capacity and potential further asset transactions.

Final Takeaway

Delek Logistics Partners delivered record Q4 and full-year results in 2025, with strong momentum across natural gas, crude, and water businesses. Management outlined a 2026 EBITDA guidance range of $520 million to $560 million, reflecting growth opportunities in the Permian Basin and an increasing proportion of third-party business. The integration of recent acquisitions and expansion of the Libby Complex continue to underpin the company’s confidence in delivering sustainable growth and long-term value for unitholders.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript
